Servile to gain: he trades for poor commodities,
And makes his conquests, thefts; some fortunate captains
That quarter with him, and are truly valiant,
Have hung the name of happy Caesar on him,
Himself never won it: he is so base and covetous,
He'll sell his sword for gold.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: This is too bitter.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O I could curse myself, that was so foolish,
So fondly childish to believe his tongue,
His promising tongue, ere I could catch his temper,
I had trash enough to have cloyed his eyes withal:
His covetous eyes; such as I scorn to tread on:
Richer then ere he saw yet, and more tempting;
Had I known he had stooped at that, I had saved mine honour,
I had been happy still: but let him take it,
And let him brag how poorly I am rewarded:
Let him go conquer still weak wretched ladies:
Love has his angry quiver too, his deadly,
And when he finds scorn, armed at the strongest:
I am a fool to fret thus, for a fool:
An old blind fool too? I lose my health: I will not
I will not cry: I will not honour him,
With tears diviner than the gods he worships:
I will not take the pains to curse a poor thing.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: Die not: you shall not need.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Would I were prisoner
To one I hate, that I might anger him,
I will love any man, to break the heart of him:
Any, that has the heart and will to kill him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take some fair truce.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will go study mischief,
And put a look on, armed with all my cunnings,
Shall meet him like a basilisque, and strike him:
Love, put destroying flames into mine eyes,
Into my smiles, deceits, that I may torture him,
That I may make him love to death, and laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Caesar commends his service to your grace.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: His service? what's his service?

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: Pray ye be patient,
The noble Caesar loves still.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What's his will?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: He craves access unto your highness

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No:
Say no: I will have none to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Good sister:

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: None I say: I will be private.
Would thou hadst flung me into Nilus (Keeper)
When first thou gavest consent, to bring my body
To this unthankful Caesar.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: 'Twas your will (Madam)
Nay more: your charge upon me, as I honoured ye:
You know what danger I endured.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Take this,
And carry it to that lordly Caesar sent thee:
There's a new love, a handsome one: a rich one:
One that will hug his mind: bid him make love to it:
Tell the ambitious broker, this will suffer —

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: He enters.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I do not use to wait (Lady)
Where I am, all the doors are free, and open.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I guess so, by your rudeness.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Ye are not angry?
Things of your tender mould, should be most gentle;
Why do you frown? good gods, what a set-anger
Have you forced into your face? Come, I must temper ye:
What a coy smile was there, and a disdainful?
How like an ominous flash it broke out from ye?
Defend me (Love) sweet, who has angered ye?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Show him a glass; that false face has betrayed me:
That base heart wrought me —

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Be more sweetly angry;
I wronged ye fair?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Away with your foul flatteries:
They are too gross: but that I dare be angry,
And with as great a god as Caesar is,
To show how poorly I respect his memory,
I would not speak to ye.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Pray ye undo this riddle,
And tell me how I have vexed ye?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Let me think first
Whether I may put on a patience
That will with honour suffer me: know, I hate ye,
Let that begin the story: now I'll tell ye.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: But do it milder: in a noble lady,
Softness of spirit, and a sober nature,
That moves like summer winds, cool: and blows sweetness;
Shows blessed like herself.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And that great blessedness
You first reaped of me, till you taught my nature
Like a rude storm to talk aloud, and thunder
Sleep was not gentler to my soul, and stiller;
You had the spring of my affections:
And my fair fruits I gave you leave to taste of:
You must expect the winter of mine anger:
You flung me off, before the court disgraced me,
When in the pride I appeared of all my beauty,
Appeared your mistress; took into your eyes
The common-strumpet love of hated lucre,
Courted with covetous heart, the slave of nature,
Gave all your thought to gold: that men of glory,
And minds adorned with noble love, would kick at:
Soldiers of royal mark, scorn such base purchase:
Beauty and honour are the marks they shoot at;
I spoke to ye then; I courted ye, and wooed ye:
Called ye dear Caesar, hung about ye tenderly:
Was proud to appear your friend.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: You have mistaken me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: But neither eye, nor favour, not a smile
Was I blessed back; but shook off rudely,
And, as ye had been sold to sordid infamy,
You fell before the images of treasure,
And in your soul you worshipped: I stood slighted,
Forgotten and contemned; my soft embraces,
And those sweet kisses you called Elysium,
As letters writ in sand, no more remembered?
The name and glory of your Cleopatra
Laughed at, and made a story to your captains:
Shall I endure?

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: You are deceived in all this,
Upon my life you are, 'tis your much tenderness.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No, no, I love not that way; you are cozened:
I love with as much ambition as a conqueror,
And where I love, will triumph.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: So you shall:
My heart shall be the chariot that shall bear ye,
All I have won shall wait upon ye: by the gods
The bravery of this woman's mind, has fired me:
Dear mistress shall I but this night? —

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How Caesar?
Have I let slip a second vanity
That give thee hope?

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: You shall be absolute,
And reign alone as Queen: you shall be any thing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Make me a maid again, and then I'll hear thee;
Examine all thy art of war, to do that;
And if thou findest it possible, I'll love thee:
Till when, farewell, unthankful.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I command.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Command, and go without, sir.
I do command thee be my slave for ever,
And vex while I laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Thus low, beauty?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: It is too late; when I have found thee absolute,
The man that fame reports thee, and to me:
May be I shall think better. Farewell conqueror. Exit.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: She mocks me too: I will enjoy her beauty:
I will not be denied; he force my longing.
Love is best pleased, when roundly we compel him,
And as he is imperious, so will I be.
Stay fool, and be advised: that dulls the appetite;
Takes of the strength and sweetness of delight.
By heaven she is a miracle, I must use
A handsome way to win: how now? what fear
Dwells in your faces? you look all distracted.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: If it be fear, 'tis fear of your undoing?
Not of ourselves: fear of your poor declining:
Our lives and deaths are equal benefits,
And we make louder prayers to die nobly,
Then to live high, and wantonly: whilst you are secure here,
And offer heccatombs of lazy kisses
To the lewd god of love, and cowardice,
And most lasciviously die in delights,
You are begirt with the fierce Alexandrians,

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: The spawn of Egypt, flow about your palace,
Armed all: and ready to assault.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Led on
By the false and base Photinus and his ministers;
No stirring out; no peeping through a loophole,
But straight saluted with an armed dart.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: No parley: they are deaf to all but danger,
They swear they will flay us, and then dry our quarters:
A rasher of a salt lover, is such a shooing-horn:
Can you kiss away this conspiracy, and set us free?
Or will the giant god of love, fight for ye?
Will his fierce warlike bow kill a cock-sparrow?
Bring out the lady, she can quell this mutiny:
And with her powerful looks, strike awe into them:
She can destroy, and build again the city,
Your goddesses have mighty gifts: show 'em her fair breasts,
The impregnable bulwarks of proud love, and let 'em
Begin their battery there: she will laugh at 'em;
They are not above a hundred thousand, sir.
A mist, a mist, that when her eyes break out,
Her powerful radiant eyes, and shake their flashes,
Will fly before her heats.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Begirt with villains?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: They come to play you, and your love a huntsup
You were told what this same whoreson wenching, long ago would come too:
You are taken napping now: has not a soldier
A time to kiss his friend, and a time to consider,
But he must lie still digging, like a pioneer,
Making of mines, and burying of his honour there?
'Twere good you would think —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And time too, or you will find else
A harder task, then courting a coy beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Look out and then believe.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: No, no, hang danger:
Take me provoking broth, and then go to her:
Go to your love, and let her feel your valour;
Charge her whole body, when the sword's in your throat (Sir,)
You may cry, Caesar, and see if that will help ye.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I'll be myself again, and meet their furies,
Meet, and consume their mischiefs: make some shift (Sceva)
To recover the fleet, and bring me up two legions,
And you shall see me, how I'll break like thunder
Amongst these beds of slimy eels, and scatter 'em.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Now ye speak sense: I'll put my life to the hazard
Before I go. No more of this warm lady,
She will spoil your sword-hand.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Go: come, let's to council
How to prevent, and then to execute.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Did ye see this penitence?

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Yes: I saw, and heard it.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: And I too: looked upon him, and observed it,
He's the strangest Septinius now —

sp.speaker: 1 sol.
sp.l: I heard he was altered,
And had given away his gold to honest uses:
Cried monstrously.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: He cries abundantly:
He is blind almost with weeping.

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis most wonderful
That a hard hearted man, and an old soldier
Should have so much kind moisture: when his mother died
He laughed aloud, and made the wickedest ballads —

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis like enough: he never loved his parents;
Nor can I blame him, for they near loved him.
His mother dreamed before she was delivered
That she was brought a-bed with a buzzard, and ever after
She whistled him up to th'world, his brave clothes too
He has flung away: and goes like one of us now:
Walks with his hands in's pockets, poor and sorrowful,
And gives the best instructions. —

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: And tells storeys
Of honest and good people that were honoured,
And how they were remembered: and runs mad
If he but hear of any ungrateful person,
A bloody, or betraying man —

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: If it be possible
That an arch-villain may ever be recovered,
This penitent rascal will put hard: 'twere worth our labour
To see him once again.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: He spares us that labour
For here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: — Bless ye my honest friends,
Bless ye from base unworthy men; come not near me:
For I am yet too taking for your company.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: What book's that?

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: No doubt
Some excellent salve for a sore heart, are you
Septinius, that base knave, that betrayed Pompey?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I was, and am; unless your honest thoughts
Will look upon my penitence, and save me
I must be ever villain: oh good soldiers
You that have Roman hearts, take heed of falsehood:
Take heed of blood; take heed of foul ingratitude,
The gods have scarce a mercy for those mischiefs,
Take heed of pride, 'twas that that brought me to it.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: This fellow would make a rare speech at the gallows

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis very fit he were hanged to edify us:

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Let all your thoughts be humble, and obedient,
Love your commanders, honour them that feed ye:
Pray, that ye may be strong in honesty
As in the use of arms; labour, and diligently
To keep your hearts from ease, and her base issues;
Pride, and ambitious wantonness, those spoilt me:
Rather lose all your limbs, than the least honesty,
You are never lame indeed, till loss of credit
Benumb ye through: scars, and those maims of honour
Are memorable crutches, that shall bear
When you are dead, your noble names to eternity.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: I cry.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: And so do I.

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: An excellent villain.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: A more sweet pious knave, I never heard yet.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: He was happy he was rascal, to come to this
Who's this? A priest?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: O stay, most holy sir!
And by the gods of Egypt, I conjure ye,
(Isis, and great Osiris) pity me,
Pity a loaden man, and tell me truly
With what most humble sacrifice I may
Wash off my sin, and appease the powers that hate me?
Take from my heart those thousand thousand furies,
That restless gnaw upon my life, and save me?
Orestes bloody hands fell on his mother,
Yet, at the holy altar he was pardoned.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Orestes out of madness did his murder,
And therefore he found grace: thou (Worst of all men)
Out of cold blood, and hope of gain, base lucre,
Slewest thine own feeder: come not near the altar,
Nor with thy reeking hands pollute the sacrifice,
Thou art marked for shame eternal. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Look all on me,
And let me be a story left to time
Of blood and infamy, how base and ugly
Ingratitude appears, with all her profits,
How monstrous, my hoped grace, at court? good soldiers
Let neither flattery, nor the witching sound
Of high and soft preferment, touch your goodness:
To be valiant, old, and honest, oh what blessedness —

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Dost thou want any thing?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Nothing but your prayers:

sp.speaker: 2 s.
sp.l: Be thus, and let the blind priest do his worst,
We have gods as well as they, and they will hear us.

sp.p: Come, cry no more: thou hast wept out twenty Pompeyes.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: So penitent?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Yet for all this
We must employ him.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: These are the armed souldier-leaders:
Away: and let's to th' fort, we shall be snapped else. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: How now? why thus? what cause of this dejection?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Why dost thou weep?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Pray leave me, you have ruined me,
You have made me a famous villain.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Does that touch thee?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He will be hard to win: he feels his lewdness,

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: He must be won, or we shall want our right hand.
This fellow dares, and knows, and must be heartened,
Art thou so poor to blench at what thou hast done?
Is conscience a comrade for an old soldier?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: It is not that: it may be some disgrace
That be takes heavily; and would be cherished,
Septinius ever scorned to show such weakness.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Let me alone; I am not for your purpose,
I am now a new man.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: We have new affairs for thee
Those that would raise thy head.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I would 'twere off,
And in your bellies for the love you bear me.
I'll be no more knave: I have stings enough
Already in my breast.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Thou shalt be noble:
And who dares think then that thou art not honest?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou shalt command in chief, all our strong forces
And if thou servest an use, must not all justify it?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am rogue enough.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Thou wilt be more, and baser:
A poor rogue is all rogues: open to all shames:
Nothing to shadow him: dost thou think crying
Can keep thee from the censure of the multitude?
Or to be kneeling at the altar save thee?
'Tis poor and servile:
Wert thou thine own sacrifice
'Twould seem so low, people would spit the fire out.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Keep thyself glorious still, though never so stained,
And that will lessen it, if not work it out
To go complaining thus: and thus repenting
Like a poor girl that had betrayed her maidenhead —

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I'll stop mine ears.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Will show so in a soldier,
So simply, and so ridicolously, so tamely —

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: If people would believe thee, 'twere some honesty,
And for thy penitence would not laugh at thee
(As sure they will) and beat thee, for thy poverty:
If they would allow thy foolery, there were some hope.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: My foolery?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Nay, more than that, thy misery,
Thy monstrous misery.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He begins to hearken:
Thy misery so great, men will not bury thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: That this were true!

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Why does this conquering Caesar
Labour through the world's deep seas of toils and troubles,
Dangers, and desperate hopes? to repent afterwards?
Why does he slaughter thousands in a battle,
And whip his country with the sword? to cry for't?
Thou killed'st great Pompey: he'll kill all his kindred,
And justify it: nay raise up trophies to it,
When thou hearest him repent: (He's held most holy too)
And cry for doing daily bloody murders,
Take thou example, and go ask forgiveness,
Call up the thing thou namest thy conscience,
And let it work: then 'twill seem well Septinius.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: He does all this.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Yes: and is honoured for it;
Nay called the honoured Caesar, so mayst thou be:
Thou wert born as near a crown as he.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: He was poor.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: And desperate bloody tricks got him this credit.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am afraid you will once more —

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Help to raise thee:
Off with thy pining black, it dulls a soldier,
And put on resolution like a man,
A noble fate waits on thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I now feel
Myself returning rascal speedily.
O that I had the power —

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all:
And do all through thy power, men shall admire thee,
And the vices of Septinius, shall turn virtues.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Off: off: thou must off: off my cowardice,
Puling repentance off.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now thou speakst nobly.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Off my dejected looks: and welcome impudence:
My daring shall be deity, to save me:
Give me instructions, and put action on me:
A glorious cause upon my sword's point (Gentlemen)
And let my wit, and valour work: you will raise me,
And make me outdare all my miseries?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: All this, and all thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Use me then,
Womanish fear farewell: I'll never melt more,
Lead on, to some great thing, to weal my spirit:
I cut the cedar Pompey, and I'll fell
This huge oak Caesar too.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now thou singest sweetly:
And Ptolemy shall crown thee for thy service:(Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He's well wrought: put him on apace for cooling.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The tumult still increases.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: O my fortune!
My lustfull folly rather! but 'tis well,
And worthily I am made a bondman's prey,
That after all my glorious victories,
In which I passed so many seas of dangers:
When all the elements conspired against me,
Would yield up the dominion of this head
To any mortal power; so blind and stupid:
To trust these base Egyptians, that proclaimed
Their perjuries, in noble Pompey's death,
And yet that could not warn me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Be still, Caesar,
Whoever loved to exercise his fate,
Where danger looked most dreadful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you fall,
Fall not alone: let the King and his sister
Be buried in your ruins: on my life
They both are guilty: reason may assure you
Photinus nor Achillas durst attempt you,
Or shake one dart, or sword, aimed at your safety,
Without their warrant.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: For the young King I know not
How he may be missed; but for his sister
(Unequalled Cleopatra) 'twere a kind
Of blasphemy to doubt her: ugly treason
Durst never dwell in such a glorious building,
Nor can so clear and great a spirit, as hers is,
Admit of falsehood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let us seize on him then:
And leave her to her fortune.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: If he have power
Use it to your security, and let
His honesty acquit him; if he be false,
It is too great an honour he should die
By your victorious hand.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: He comes: and I
Shall do as I find cause.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Let not great Caesar
Impute the breach of hospitality,
To you (My guest) to me; I am contemned,
And my rebellious subjects lift their hands
Against my head: and would they aimed no farther,
Provided that I fell a sacrifice
To gain you safety: that this is not feigned,
The boldness of my innocence may confirm you:
Had I been privy to their bloody plot,
I now had led them on, and given fair gloss
To their bad cause, by being present with them:
But I that yet taste of the punishment,
In being false to Pompey, will not make
A second fault to Caesar uncompelled
With such as have not yet shook off obedience,
I yield myself to you, and will take part
In all your dangers.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: This pleads your excuse,
And I receive it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: If they have any touch,
Of justice, or religion, I will use
The authority of our gods, to call them back,
From their bad purpose.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: This part of the palace,
Is yet defensible: we may make it good,
Till your powers rescue us.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Caesar besieged?
O stain to my great actions: 'twas my custom
An army routed, as my feet had wings
To be first in the chase: nor walls, nor bulwarks
Could guard those that escaped the battle's fury
From this strong arm, and I to be enclosed
My heart! my heart! but 'tis necessity,
To which the gods must yield, and I obey,
Till I redeem it, by some glorious way. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: There's no retiring now, we are broke in:
The deed passed hope of pardon: if we prosper
'A will be styled lawful, and we shall give laws
To those that now command us: stop not at
Or loyalty, or duty, bold ambition,
To dare and power to do, gave the first difference
Between the King, and subject, Caesar's motto,
Aut Caesar aut nihil, each of us must claim,
And use it as our own.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: The deed is bloody
If we conclude in Ptolemy's death.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: The better
The globe of empire must be so manured.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Rome, that from Romulus first took her name
Had her walls watered with a crimson shower
Drained from a brother's heart: nor was she raised
To this prodigious height, that overlooks
Three full parts of the earth, that pay her tribute,
But by enlarging of her narrow bounds
By the sack of neighbour cities, were made hers
Till they were cemented with the blood of those
That did possess 'em: Cesar, Ptolemy,
(Now I am steeled) to me are empty names
Esteemed as Pompey's was.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Well said Septinius,
Thou now art right again.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: But what course take we
For the Princess Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Let her live
A while to make us sport: she shall authorise
Our undertakings to the ignorant people,
As if what we do were by her command:
But our triumvirate government once confirmed,
She bears her brother company, that's my province:
Leave me to work her.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I will undertake
For Ptolemy.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Cesar shall be my task,
And as in Pompey I began a names
I'll perfect it in Caesar.

div.stage: Enter (Above) Caesar, Ptolemy, Achoreus, Appollodorus, Anthony, Dollabella.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved then
We'll force our passage.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: See: they do appear
As they desired a parley.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I am proud yet
I have brought them to capitulate.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Now Photinus?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now Ptolemy?

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: No addition?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: We are equal,
Though Caesar's name were put into the scale,
In which our worth is weighed.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Presumptuous villain,
Upon what grounds hast thou presumed to raise
Thy servile hand against the King, or me,
That have a greater name?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: On those, by which
Thou didst presume to pass the Rubicon
Against the laws of Rome; and at the name
Of traitor smile, as thou didst when Marcellus
The consul, with the senate's full consent
Pronounced thee for an enemy to thy country,
Yet thou wentest on, and thy rebellious cause
Was crowned with fair success: why should we fear then?
Think on that Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: O the gods! be braved thus?
And be compelled to bear this from a slave
That would not brook great Pompey his superior?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thy glories now have touched the highest point,
And must descend.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Despair, and think we stand
The champions of Rome, to wreak her wrongs
Upon whose liberty thou hast set thy foot.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: And that the ghosts of all those noble Romans
That by thy sword fell in this civil war,
Expect revenge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Darest thou speak, and remember
There was a Pompey?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: There is no hope to scape us:
If that against the odds we have upon you
You dare come forth and fight, receive the honour
To die, like Romans, if ye faint, resolve
To starve, like wretches: I disdain to changeExit.
Another syllable with you.

sp.speaker: An●.
sp.l: Let us die nobly:
And rather fall upon each others sword
Then come into these villains hands.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: That fortune
Which to this hour hath been a friend to Caesar,
Though for a while she clothe her brow with frowns
Will smile again upon me; who will pay her,
Or sacrifice or vows, if she forsake
Her best of works in me? or suffer him
Whom, with a strong hand she hath led triumphant
Through the whole western world, and Rome acknowledged
Her sovereign lord, to end in gloriously,
A life admired by all? the threatened danger
Must by a way more horrid, be avoided,
And I will run the hazard: fire the palace,
And the rich magazines that neighbour it,
In which the wealth of Egypt is contained:
Start not, it shall be so; that while the people
Labour in quenching the ensuing flames,
Like Caesar, with this handful of my friends
Through fire, and swords, I force a passage to
My conquering legions. King, if thou dar'st follow
Where Caesar leads, or live, or die a freeman;
If not, stay here a bondman to thy slave,
And dead, be thought unworthy of a grave. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I feel my resolution melts again,
And that I am not knave alone, but fool
In all my purposes. This devil Photinus
Employs me, as a property, and grown useless
Will shake me off again: he told me so
When I killed Pompey: nor can I hope better
When Caesar is dispatched: services done
For such as only study their own ends,
Too great to be rewarded, or returned
With deadly hate: I learned this principle
In his own school: yet still he fooles me: well:
And yet he trusts me; since I in my nature
Was fashioned to be false, wherefore should I
That killed my general, and a roman, one
To whom I owe all nourishments of life
Be true to an Egyptian? to save Caesar,
And turn Photinus plots on his own head,
As it is in my power, redeem my credit,
And live, to lie, and swear again in fashion,
O, 'twere a masterpiece? ha? — me Ceasar,
How's he got off?

div.stage: Enter Caesar, Ptolemy, Antony, Dollabella. Achoreus, Appollodorus, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: The fire has taken,
And shows the city, like a second Troy,
The navy too is scorched, the people greedy
To save their wealth, and houses, while their soldiers
Make spoil of all: only Achillas troops
Make good their guard: break through them, we are safe:
I'll lead you like a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Stay Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Who's this? the dog Septinius?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: You barked but now, fawn you so soon?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: O hear me,
What I'll deliver is for Caesar's safety,
For all your good.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good from a month like thine,
That never belched but blasphemy and treason, on festival days

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am an altered man: altered indeed,
And I will give you cause to say I am a roman.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Rogue, I grant thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Trust me, I'll make the passage smooth and easy,
For your escape.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll trust the devil sooner,
And make a safer bargain.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am trusted,
With all Photinus secrets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's no doubt then,
Thou wilt be false.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Still to be true to you.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And very likely.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Be brief, the means?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Thus Caesar:
To me alone, but bound by terrible oaths
Not to discover it, he hath revealed
A dismal vault, whose dreadful mouth does open
A mile beyond the city: in this cave
Lie but two hours concealed.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: If you believe him,
He'll bury us alive.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I'll fly in the air first.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Then in the dead of night, I'll bring you back
Into a private room, where you shall find
Photinus, and Achillas, and the rest
Of their commanders, close at counsel.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Good: what follows?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Fall me fairly on their throats,
Their heads cut off and shorn, the multitude
Will easily disperse.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: O devil! away with him:
Nor true to friend nor enemy? Caesar scorns
To find his safety, or revenge his wrongs
So base a way: or owe the means of life
To such a leprous traitor. I have towered
For victory like a falcon in the clouds,
Not digged for't like a mole: our swords, and cause
Make way for us; and that it may appear
We took a noble course, and hate base treason,
Some soldiers, that would merit Caesar's favour,
Hang him on yonder turret, and then follow
The lane, this sword makes for you. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Here's a belt,
Though I die for it I'll use it.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: 'Tis too good
To truss a cur in.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Save me, here's gold.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: If Rome
Were offered for thy ransom, it could not help thee.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Hang not an arse.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Goad him on with thy sword:
Thou dost deserve a worser end; and may
All such conclude so, that their friends betray.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We are lost.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: Undone.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Confusion, fire, and swords,
And fury in the soldier's face, more horrid
Circle us round.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: The Kings command they laugh at,
And jeer at Caesar's threats.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: My brother seized on
By the roman, as thought guilty of the tumult,
And forced to bear him company, as marked out
For his protection, or revenge.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: They have broke
Into my cabinet: my trunks are ransacked.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have lost my jewels too; but that's the least:
The barbarous rascals, against all humanity,
Or sense of pity, have killed my little dog,
And broke my monkeys chain.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: They ruffled me:
But that I could endure, and tire 'em too,
Would they proceed no further.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O my sister!

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: My Queen, my mistress!

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Can you stand unmoved
When an earthquake of rebellion shakes the city?
And the court trembles?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Yes Arsino,
And with a masculine constancy deride
Fortune's worst malice, as a servant to
My virtues, not a mistress: than we forsake
The strong fort of ourselves, when we once yield,
Or shrink at her assaults; I am still myself,
And though disrobed of sovereignty, and ravished
Of ceremonious duty, that attends it,
Nay, grant they had slaved my body, my free mind
Like to the palmtree, walling fruitful Nile,
Shall grow up straighter, and enlarge itself
Spite of the envious weight that loads it with:
Think of thy birth (Arsino) common burdens
Fit common shoulders; teach the multitude
By suffering nobly what they fear to touch at:
The greatness of thy mind does soar a pitch,
Their dim eyes (Darkened by their narrow souls)
Cannot arrive at.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am new created,
And owe this second being to you (Best sister)
For now I feel you have infused into me
Part of your fortitude.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: I still am fearful:
I dare not tell a lie: you that were born
Daughters, and sisters unto Kings, may nourish
Great thoughts, which I, that am your humble handmaid
Must not presume to rival.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Yet (My Erisychthon)
Though thou hast profited nothing, by observing
The whole course of my life, learn in my death,
Though not to equal, yet to imitate
Thy fearless mistress.

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: O, a man in arms?
His weapon drawn too?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Though upon the point
Death sat, I'll meet it, and outdare the danger.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Keep the watch strong, and guard the passage sure
That leads unto the sea.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What sea of rudeness
Breaks in upon us? or what subject's breath
Dare raise a storm, when we command a calm?
Are duty, and obedience fled to heaven,
And in their room, ambition and pride
Sent into Egypt? that face speaks thee Photinus,
A thing thy mother brought into the world:
My brothers, and my slave: but thy behaviour,
Opposed to that an insolent intruder
Upon that sovereignty thou shouldst bow to,
If in the gulf of base ingratitude,
All loyalty to Ptolemy the King
Be swallowed up, remember who I am,
Whose daughter, and whose sister: or suppose
That is forgotten too; let the name of Caesar
Which nations quake at, stop the desperate madness
From running headlong on to thy confusion.
Throw from thee quickly those rebellious arms,
And let me read submission in thine eyes,
Ahy wrongs to us, we will not only pardon,
But be a ready advocate, to plead for thee
To Caesar, and my brother.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Plead my pardon?
To you I bow, but scorn as much to stoop thus
To Ptolemy, to Caesar? Nay the gods,
As to put off the figure of a man,
And change my essence, with a sensual beast:
All my designs, my counsels, and dark ends
Were aimed to purchase you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How durst thou, being
The scorn of baseness, nourish such a thought?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They that have power are royal: and those base
That live at the devotion of another,
What birth gave Ptolemy, or fortune Caesar,
By engines fashioned in this Protean anvil
I have made mine: and only stoop at you,
Whom I would still preserve free to command me;
For Caesar's frowns, they are below my thoughts,
And but in these fair eyes, I still have read
The story of a supreme monarchy,
To which all hearts with mine, gladly pay tribute,
Photinus' name, had long since been as great
As Ptolemy's e'er was, or Caesar's is,
This made me as a weaker tie to unloose
The knot of loyalty, that chained my freedom;
And slight the fear that Caesar's threats might cause,
That I and they might see no sun appear
But Cleopatra, in th' Egyptian sphere.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O giantlike ambition! married to
Cimmerian darkness! in considerate fool,
(Though flattered with self love) couldst thou believe,
Were all crowns on the earth, made into one,
And that (By Kings) set on thy head: all sceptres,
Within thy grasp, and laid down at my feet,
I would vouchsafe a kiss to a no-man?
A gelded eunuch?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Fairest, that makes for me:
And shows it is no sensual appetite,
But true love to the greatness of thy spirit,
That when that you are mine shall yield me pleasures:
Hymen, though blessing a new married pair
Shall blush to think on, and our certain issue,
The glorious splendour of dread majesty:
Whose beams shall dazzle Rome, and awe the world:
My wants in that kind, others shall supply,
And I give way to it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Baser than thy birth:
Can there be gods, and hear this, and no thunder,
Ram thee into the earth?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They are asleep ,
And cannot hear thee:
Or with open eyes,
Did Jove look on us, I would laugh and swear
That his artillery is cloyed by me:
Or if that they have power to hurt, his bolts
Are in my hand.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Most impious!

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They are dreams,
Religious fools shake at: yet to assure thee,
If Nemesis, that scourges pride, and scorn,
Be any thing but a name she lives in me:
For by myself (An oath to me more dreadful
Than Styx is to your gods) weak Ptolemy dead,
And Caesar (Both being in my toil) removed
The poorest rascals, that are in my camp
Shall, in my presence, quench their justful heat
In thee, and young Arsinoe; while I laugh
To hear you howl in vain:
I deride those gods,
That you think can protect you,

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: To prevent thee,
In that I am the mistress of my fate:
So hope I of my sister, to confirm it,
I spit at thee, and scorn thee.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I will tame,
That haughty courage, and make it stoop too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Never:
I was born to command and I will die so.

div.stage: Enter Achillas and soldiers, with the body of Ptolemy.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: The King dead? this is a fair entrance to,
Our future happiness.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O my dear brother?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Weep not Arsinoe, common women do so,
Nor lose a tear for him, it cannot help him:
But study to die nobly.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Caesar fled?
'Tis deadly aconite to my cold heart:
It chokes my vital spirits: where was your care?
Did the guards sleep?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He roused them with his sword:
We talk of Mars, but I am sure his courage
Admits of no comparison but itself,
And (As inspired by him) his following friends
With such a confidence, as you eaglets prey
Under the large wing of their fiercer dam,
Broke through our troops, and scattered 'em, he went on:
But still pursued by us: when on the sudden,
He turned his head, and from his eyes flew terror;
Which struck in us no less fear, and amazement,
Then if we had encountered with the lightning,
Hurled from Jove's cloudy brow.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: 'Twas like my Caesar.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: We fallen back, he made on, and as our fear
Had parted from us, with his dreadful looks,
Again we followed: but got near the sea:
On which his navy anchor; in one hand
Holding a scroll he had, above the waves,
And in the other grasping fast his sword
As it had been a trident, forged by Vulcan,
To calm the raging ocean, he made away
As if he had been neptune: his friends like
So many Tritons followed their bold shouts,
Yielding a cheerful music; we showered darts,
Upon them but in vain, they reached their ships,
And in their safety we are sunk; for Caesar
Prepares for war.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: How fell the King?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Unable,
To follow Caesar, he was trod to death
By the pursuers, and with him the priest,
Of Isis' good Achoreus.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: May the earth,
Lie gently on their ashes.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I feel now,
That there are powers above us: and that 'tis not
Within the searching policies of man,
To alter their decrees.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I laugh at thee:
Where are thy threats now, (Fool) thy scoffs, and scorns
Against the gods? I see calamity
Is the best mistress of religion,
And can convert an atheist.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: O they come,
Mountains fall on me! O, for him to die
That placed his heaven on earth, is an assurance
Of his descent to hell; where shall I hide me?
The greatest daring to a man dishonest,
Is but a bastard courage, ever fainting. Exit.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.p: Look on your Caesar; banish fear (My fairest) you now are safe.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: By Venus, not a kiss
Till our work be done: the traitors once dispatched
To it, and we'll cry aim.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I will be speedy. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Farewell again Arsinoe; how now Erisychthon,
Ever faint-hearted?

sp.speaker: Aeros.
sp.l: But that I am assured,
Your excellency can command the general,
I fear the soldiers, for they look as if
They would be nibbling too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is all honour,
Nor do I now repent me of my favours;
Nor can I think nature e'er made a woman,
That in her prime deserved him.

div.stage: Enter Caesar, Sceva, Antony, Dollabella, soldiers, with the heads.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: He's come back,
Pursue no farther; curb the soldier's fury.
See (Beauteous mistress) their accursed heads,
That did conspire against us.

sp.speaker: Sceva.
sp.l: Furies plague 'em,
They had too fair an end, to die like soldiers,
Pompey fell by the sword; the cross, or halter
Should have dispatched them.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: All is but death (Good Sceva)
Be therefore satisfied, and now (My dearest)
Look up on Caesar, as he still appeared
A conqueror, and this unfortunate King
Entombed with honour, we'll for Rome, where Caesar
Will show he can give kingdom: for the senate,
(Thy brother dead) shall willingly decree
The crown of Egypt, (That was his) to thee.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: New titles, warrant not a play for new,
The subject being old: and 'tis as true,
Fresh, and neat matter may with ease be framed
Out of their storeys, that have oft been named
With glory on the stage: what borrows he
From him that wrote old Priam's tragedy.
That writes bis love to Hecuba? Sure, to tell
Of Caesar's amorous heats, and how he fell
In the Capitol, can never be the same
To the judicious: nor will such blame
Those that penned this, for barrenness when they find
Young Cleopatra here, and her great mind
Expressed to the height, with us a maid, and free,
And how he rated her virginity.
We treat not of what boldness she did die,
Nor of her fatal love to Anthony.
What we present and offer to your view,
(Upon their faiths) the stage yet never knew.
Let reason then, first to your wills give laws,
And after judge of them, and of their cause.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: I now should wish another had my place,
But that I hope to come off, and with grace.
And but express some sign that you are pleased,
We of our doubts, they of their fears are eased.
I would beg further (Gentlemen) and much say
In the favour of ourselves, them, and the play;
Did I not rest assured; the most I see
Hate impudence, and cherish modesty.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
